days.subtopic: Introduction to Digestion: What is Digestion?
objectives: Learner should be able to define digestion.
Learner should be able to explain the importance of digestion for the human body.
teacher_activity: Warm-up: Ask learners what happens to the food they eat.
Introduce the main topic: 'The Human Body: Digestion Introduction'.
Clearly define digestion using simple language and relatable examples (e.g., breaking down large food particles into smaller ones for the body to use).
Explain the importance of digestion for obtaining energy, growth, and repair of body tissues.
Engage learners in a brief discussion to check their initial understanding and address any misconceptions.
learner_activity: Participate actively in the warm-up discussion.
Listen attentively and take notes on the definition and importance of digestion.
Ask clarifying questions where necessary.
Copy the definition of digestion from the board into their notebooks.
materials: Grade 7 Science Textbook (e.g., 'Primary Science Learner's Book Grade 7')
days.assignment: In your own words, write down the definition of digestion and why it is important.

days.subtopic: Introduction to the Organs of the Digestive System (Part 1: Mouth, Oesophagus, Stomach)
objectives: Learner should be able to identify the mouth, oesophagus, and stomach as organs of the digestive system.
Learner should be able to state the primary function of the mouth, oesophagus, and stomach.
teacher_activity: Recap the definition of digestion from the previous day.
Introduce the concept of a 'system' in the human body, focusing on the digestive system.
Display a large, clear diagram or chart of the human digestive system.
Point out and briefly describe the role of the mouth (chewing, mixing with saliva), oesophagus (food pipe, movement of food to stomach), and stomach (churning food, mixing with digestive juices).
Encourage learners to locate these organs on the diagram and, where appropriate, on their own bodies.
learner_activity: Answer questions during the recap.
Observe the digestive system diagram/chart carefully.
Identify and label the mouth, oesophagus, and stomach on the diagram.
Take notes on the name and basic function of each organ.
Participate in a Q&A session to deepen understanding.
materials: Large Diagram/Chart of the Human Digestive System
days.assignment: Draw and label the mouth, oesophagus, and stomach in your notebook. Briefly describe one function for each.

days.subtopic: Introduction to the Organs of the Digestive System (Part 2: Small Intestine, Large Intestine, Anus)
objectives: Learner should be able to identify the small intestine, large intestine, and anus as organs of the digestive system.
Learner should be able to state the primary function of the small intestine, large intestine, and anus.
teacher_activity: Quick recap of the digestive organs covered on Tuesday (mouth, oesophagus, stomach).

Using the same diagram/chart, point out and briefly describe the role of the small intestine (main site for nutrient absorption), large intestine (water absorption, formation of faeces), and anus (egestion/removal of undigested waste).
Emphasize the sequential flow of food through these organs.
Facilitate a short group activity: Provide learners with names of organs and their functions on separate cards; they match them correctly.
learner_activity: Participate in the recap session.
Observe the diagram/chart to locate the new organs.
Identify and label the small intestine, large intestine, and anus.
Take notes on the name and basic function of each new organ.
Actively participate in the organ-function matching activity.
materials: Large Diagram/Chart of the Human Digestive System
Prepared flashcards for matching activity (organ names vs. functions)
days.assignment: List all six main organs of the digestive system in the correct order that food passes through them.

days.subtopic: Review and Consolidation of Digestion and Digestive Organs
objectives: Learner should be able to accurately define digestion.
Learner should be able to correctly identify all major organs of the digestive system from a diagram or list.
Learner should be able to state the basic function of each major digestive organ.
teacher_activity: Begin with a brainstorming session: 'What have we learned about digestion this week?'
Draw a simplified, unlabeled diagram of the digestive system on the board. Invite learners to come up and label the organs one by one.
Ask questions about the definition of digestion and the specific function of each organ.
Address any common misconceptions or areas where learners are struggling.
Conduct a quick oral quiz or 'pop quiz' covering the key definitions and organ identification/functions.
learner_activity: Actively participate in the brainstorming session and labeling activity.
Answer teacher's questions about digestion and organ functions.
Ask clarifying questions to solidify their understanding.
Participate in the oral or written pop quiz to self-assess their learning.
materials: Diagram/Chart of the Human Digestive System (for reference)
days.assignment: Review all your notes on digestion and the digestive organs in preparation for a short assessment tomorrow.

objectives: Learner should be able to demonstrate their understanding of digestion and the major digestive organs through a short written assessment.
teacher_activity: Distribute a short written quiz (10-15 minutes) covering:
- Definition of digestion.
- Identification of digestive organs (from a provided diagram or list).
- Basic functions of 2-3 key digestive organs.
Collect the quizzes and provide brief feedback on common strengths and areas for improvement (if time permits).
Provide praise for effort and understanding.
Briefly introduce what will be covered in the next lesson/week (e.g., accessory organs of digestion, mechanical vs. chemical digestion).
learner_activity: Attempt the quiz individually and to the best of their ability.
Hand in their completed quizzes.
Listen to feedback and note down any areas requiring further review.
Prepare for the upcoming topics based on the teacher's introduction.
days.assignment: No new assignment. Learners should review their quiz results and notes to correct any errors.
